titleStmt.title: SII 14.49: original edition by A. S. Ramanatha Ayyar
No. 49. (A.R. No. 287 of 1923.) TIRUKKŌṬṬIYŪR, TIRUPPATTUR TALUK, RAMANATHAPURAM DISTRICT. ON A SLAB IN THE STORE-ROOM OF THE SAUMYANĀRĀYAṆA-PERUMĀḶ TEMPLE.

summary.p: This Vaṭṭeḻuttu record which is let into the wall of the store-room and is kept bottom up, is dated in the 2+1st year of Śaḍaiya-Māṟaṉ. The secondary i loop is attached to the top of the respective consonants and not to the side. The record which may be assigned to the time of Rājasimha must have belonged to Śiva temple at the village, though it is now found embedded in the wall of the Vishṇu temple. It registers a gift of a perpetual lamp by a certain AṇukkiAṇukki indicates that the woman was a lady-in-waiting at the royal court.-Sundaravalli of Kaṇṇikuḍi in KIḻ-Iraṇiyamuṭṭam to the god Periya-ŚrIkōyil-BhaTAra of TirukkōTTiyūr.

Above this record is another short one registering a gift of cows and sheep for a lamp by a merchant named Kaṇḍaṉ-Śaṅkaranāraṇaṉ, and belonging to about the same period. The damaged portion consisting of a few Sanskrit verses is not decipherable, and as only a few words are legible here and there, such as Śrīgōshṭhinātha in line 6, no continuous sense can be made out.

revisionDesc.change: Further conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)

div.p:
svasti śrī . koccaṭaiyamāṟa
ṟku yāṇṭiraṇṭu Itaṉ ṉe
tirāmāṇṭu tevatāṉan tiruk
koṭṭiyūr periya śrīkoyil
paṭāraṟku ciḻiraṇiyamuṭṭa
ttu kaṇṇikuṭic colama
pirāṭṭiyāṉa Aṇukki cu
ntaravalli vaitta tiruno
ntā viḷak koṉṟu.
3) After line 9, a few damaged letters of a Sanskrit portion are seen—

yasyāsvadhuramathaḥ karoti vana
cāru : vendrāṅganā
śām �nāyakara vanaḥ
sraṣṭorvadhesānārāya
veṣṭhiṣu �vo
śrīgoṣṭhinātha
niti matikacoḷi ma
Above this record is engraved the following:—

periya śrī koyil paṭā
raṟku viyāpāri kaṇṭañ
caṅkaranāraṇaṉ nicati
ppaṭi Uriy neyeriva
tāka vacca tirunontā
viḷak koṉṟu pacu paṉ
ṉiraṇṭu Āṭu Aimpatu .
Digital edition of SII 14.49 by converted to DHARMA conventions by Emmanuel Francis.
